speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when these symptoms started? Was it sudden or did they develop gradually?

speaker: Patient
text: It all started about a year ago, to be honest. I just felt really overwhelmed and anxious all the time, and I started hearing these... voices. At first, I thought I was just stressed out from work, but as time went on, the voices just kept getting louder and more persistent.

speaker: Doctor
text: When did you first notice the difficulty swallowing, and did you experience any other symptoms such as pain, nausea, or vomiting at the same time?

speaker: Patient
text: The swallowing issue started about a month ago, and it's been really frustrating because I feel like I'm choking all the time. I haven't experienced any pain or nausea with it, but I do get a bit lightheaded when I try to swallow.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the involuntary movements you've been experiencing? Were they isolated to one area of your body or did they seem to be widespread?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, it's been really hard to describe, but it's like my body feels like it's moving on its own sometimes. My hands, my feet, even my face – it's like I'm going through the motions, but I'm not really in control.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to examine your throat and mouth to check for any signs of inflammation or irritation. Can you please open your mouth and show me your tongue, and then I'd like to gently feel the base of your tongue and the roof of your mouth?

speaker: Patient
text: I'll try my best to show you what you're looking for. *opens mouth and shows tongue* I'm not sure what to expect, but I'll do my best. *proceeds to place tongue at the back of the mouth and allows doctor to examine* Go ahead and feel around.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe the involuntary movements in more detail - are they twitching, jerking, or a sort of stiffening of the muscles?

speaker: Patient
text: It's like my body is shaking, but not just my hands or my arms, it's like everything is trembling. Sometimes it feels like my whole body is stiff, like I'm frozen in place, but other times it's like I'm bouncing around in my seat. It's really hard to explain, and it's making me feel really anxious and scared.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me about your daily activities and routine? Do you find that certain tasks or activities trigger or relieve these symptoms?



Also, have you noticed any recent changes in your sleep patterns or appetite?



I'd like to take a closer look at your tongue and the base of your mouth. Is there any numbness, tingling, or burning sensation in that area?



REQUEST TEST: EMG to assess muscle activity

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the types of involuntary movements you've been experiencing - are they more pronounced at certain times of the day or when you're under stress?

speaker: Patient
text: It's like my body is just doing its own thing, you know? Sometimes it's more noticeable when I'm feeling really anxious or overwhelmed, like I just can't seem to calm down. And it's not just the big movements, either - it's like my whole body is twitching, even when I'm just sitting still.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe the types of involuntary movements you've been experiencing in more detail, such as are they affecting your arms, legs, or any other parts of your body?

speaker: Patient
text: It's like my whole body is just... uncoordinated, I guess. My arms, my legs, my face – everything feels like it's moving on its own, like I'm a puppet and someone else is pulling the strings. And it's not just the big movements, either – even my fingers and toes seem to be twitching all the time.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your responses. It sounds like your symptoms have been ongoing for some time, and they've been affecting your daily activities. Can you tell me more about the types of activities that trigger or relieve your symptoms?

speaker: Patient
text:
I'd say that when I'm trying to focus on something, like reading or watching TV, my symptoms seem to be triggered. But when I'm doing something that requires my hands to be still, like drawing or knitting, they seem to be relieved. It's like my body is more active when I'm trying to do something else with my hands.

I've also noticed that my symptoms tend to worsen when I'm in crowded spaces or around loud noises. It's like my brain gets overwhelmed and my body just starts reacting.

And I've been feeling really anxious and stressed out lately, especially since I lost my job. I guess that's just making things worse.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your daily activities and routine, specifically what you do in the morning to get ready for the day? Do you find that certain tasks, such as eating or speaking, trigger or relieve your symptoms?

speaker: Patient
text: I try to get ready for the day by doing some light stretching and taking a short walk around the block, just to get my blood flowing. I also try to eat a healthy breakfast to start the day off right, but to be honest, sometimes I just can't seem to focus on my breakfast because my mind starts racing and I hear those voices again. And when I'm trying to speak to people, especially if I'm on the phone or in a meeting, I find that my symptoms can get really bad - my hands start shaking and my words get all jumbled up.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your morning routine, specifically what's the first thing you do after waking up?

speaker: Patient
text: It's pretty simple, I just wake up, and I try to get out of bed as quickly as possible, you know? I've got a lot to do in the morning, and I like to get a head start.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the first thing you do after waking up? Do you find that you're able to get out of bed easily, or do you need some time to get moving before you're feeling okay?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, it takes me a bit to get out of bed. Sometimes I feel really groggy and disoriented, like I'm still half asleep. I have to make a few cups of coffee before I can even think about getting out of bed, and even then, I'm not always feeling 100%.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your sleep patterns, especially at night - do you find that your symptoms worsen or improve during certain stages of sleep?

speaker: Patient
text: I've been having trouble sleeping at night, to be honest. Sometimes I'll lie awake for hours, my mind racing and the voices in my head getting louder and more persistent. And when I do manage to fall asleep, I often wake up feeling really disoriented and groggy, like I've been hit by a truck.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you describe the types of involuntary movements you've been experiencing in more detail - are they affecting your arms, legs, or any other parts of your body?



Also, have you noticed any recent changes in your mental clarity or focus, such as difficulty concentrating or remembering things?



Please continue to open your mouth and let me examine your tongue and the base of your mouth more closely.

speaker: Patient
text:
It's like my whole body is just... uncoordinated, I guess. My arms, my legs, my face – everything feels like it's moving on its own, like I'm a puppet and someone else is pulling the strings. And it's not just the big movements, either – even my fingers and toes seem to be twitching all the time.

As for my mental clarity, I'd say it's been a struggle lately. I find myself getting distracted easily, and I have trouble remembering things. It's like my brain is foggy, and I'm not really sure what's going on. Sometimes I'll be in the middle of a conversation, and I'll just stop and stare, like I forgot what we were talking about. It's really frustrating.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me more about your mental clarity and focus - have you noticed any difficulty concentrating or remembering things recently?



Also, can you show me the tongue and base of your mouth again, and I'd like to take a closer look at the uvula and the tonsils for any signs of inflammation or irritation?



I'd like to request a test to check for any abnormalities in your thyroid function, given the difficulty swallowing and involuntary movements. REQUEST TEST: TSH

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to ask about your diet and eating habits - have you noticed any changes in the types of foods that trigger or relieve your symptoms?

speaker: Patient
text: I've noticed that certain foods can really affect my symptoms. I'm not sure if it's just my imagination, but I feel like spicy foods or strong smells can really trigger my movements and voices. On the other hand, simple foods like toast or plain crackers seem to calm me down a bit. It's like my body is super sensitive to certain things.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me about any recent changes in your diet or eating habits, such as have you started eating any new foods or noticed any sensitivity to certain types of food?



Also, when you eat, do you find that your symptoms improve or worsen, or is it more of a neutral effect?



Can you show me your hands again, and I'd like to gently check for any stiffness or tremors in your fingers?



Also, have you noticed any recent changes in your emotional state or mood, such as feelings of anxiety or depression?



Please open your mouth again and let me take a closer look at the uvula and the tonsils to see if there's any inflammation or irritation.

speaker: Patient
text:
I'd say my emotions have been all over the place lately. One minute I'm feeling really anxious and overwhelmed, and the next minute I'm feeling numb and detached. It's like my emotions are just floating around inside me, and I'm not really sure how to control them.

Can you tell me more about the findings from the brain MRI? I've heard that it can show some pretty interesting things about the brain.

And can you please be more gentle when you're examining my hands? I'm really sensitive to touch right now, and it's making me feel a bit anxious.

I'd say that my emotional state has been triggered by a lot of stress and anxiety in my life, especially since I lost my job. But at the same time, I feel like I'm just really struggling to cope with everything that's going on. It's like my brain is just overwhelmed, and I don't know how to turn it off.

Can you please take a closer look at the uvula

speaker: Doctor
text:
I've taken note of all your responses. It seems like you've been experiencing a range of symptoms, including difficulty swallowing, involuntary movements, and changes in sleep patterns and appetite. Based on the information you've provided, I'm going to request a few more tests to help narrow down the possible causes of your symptoms.

REQUEST TEST: Imaging studies to evaluate the neurological system, such as an MRI or CT scan.

Can you tell me more about your emotional state and mood - have you noticed any feelings of anxiety or depression, or any other changes in your emotional well-being?

Can you describe your current level of energy and fatigue - do you feel like you're able to get through your day without needing to rest, or do you feel tired or lethargic more often?

Please continue to open your mouth and let me examine your tongue and the base of your mouth more closely.
